body:
The default turbidity factor changed in 2006, but it seems Axel must  
have been using an older version of gensky.  Neither the new result or  
the old result is "correct" in the sense that the sky is unreal.   
Absolute values never mean much in daylighting calculations unless you  
have a measured sky.  This is why we recommend using the -B (-r) and - 
R (-r) options to calibrate gensky output against measurements if you  
care about absolute levels.


-Greg
___
<sup>Automatically generated content from [radiance mailing-list](https://radiance-online.org/pipermail/radiance-general/2010-June/007007.html).</sup>
